AT&T Announces Gift of
$4000 for EE Department
At an informal awards
ceremony on Tuesday, James
W. Smith, a representative
from AT&T Information
Systems, presented to the Johns
Hopkins Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science a gift of $4000 in
order to establish two student
awards and support the work of
the local chapters of three
engineering student organizations.
According to Smith, AT&T
is giving $1000 to establish two
$500
no-strings-attached
awards for the department's
top junior and senior students,
$2000 to support the work of
the Institute of Electrical and
Electronic Engineers (IEEE),
the Association for Computing
Machines (ACM), and Eta

Kappa Nu, and $1000 for the
upcoming ACM programming
contest.
Fredrick Davidson, Chairman of the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science who accepted the
gift on behalf of his department
and the university, said, "I'm
delighted by the generosity of
AT&T Information Systems.
It's difficult to get funds to support the activities of our
engineering student organizations so this award means a
lot."
Davidson also said that the
two student awards will be called the "William H. Huggins
Awards" in honor of a former
department professor who
"provided leadership, scholarship, and service to the depart-

ment for more than three
decades."
Smith added that the Huggins Awards will be given to
students who have "provided
outstanding service to the
department and to his/her
fellow students through participation in engineering student organizations or through
individual activities" in addition to maintaining an excellent
academic record.
According to Smith, AT&T
Information Systems is making
the $4000 gift available to
Hopkins this year on a trial
basis. "We'll evaluate how it
works this year," he said.
"Then we may consider making it available in upcoming
years."

supported a variety of programs, including:

the restaurant with light and
overlooks the patio. Once the
warmer weather arrives,
customers may sit outside
where they can dine among the
museum's sculptures and
shrubbery.

selection of unique foods and
drinks available throughout the
day and evening. The cafe offers different types of snacks
and entrees to accomodate
one's appetite and the time of
day. It is open after museum
hours, serving Lite Fare and
Dinner Tuesday-Saturday until
11:00 p.m. and Sunday until
9:00 p.m. Sunday Brunch is
available from 11:00 a.m. until 3:00 p.m. Both the museum
and the cafe are closed on
Mondays.

pasta salad of spinach and egg
a loodles, tossed with fresh

vegetables and imported
cheeses, $4.50), the Virginia
Club (roast turkey breast and
Smithfield Ham on light and
dark bread, $5.50), and the
Cafe Burger (a broiled burger
topped with fried onions and
melted New York cheddar
cheese, served on an onion
Kaiser roll with lettuce and
tomato, $4.95). The luncheon
menu varies in price from $4.50
to $6.50 for entrees, and from
$2.25 to $5.95 for exotic appetizers, soups and salads.

vegetables, and a basket of
warm rye sticks. Starting at

Tournedos Dijonnaise (two
petit filet mignons on Dijon
mustard croutons, served with
a sauce of burgundy wine,
shallots, and mushrooms,
$12.95) is highly recommended.
After dinner, one may
choose a scrumptious selection
from the pastry tray and try one
of many teas, coffees, dessert
drinks, or cordials.
Whether you are strolling
through the museum and are
overcome by hunger, or feel
that you deserve to sample
superior fare, the Museum Cafe
should rise to the top of your
list.

The Ladykillers, 1955, Britain. Director: Alexander MacKendrick. Cast: Alec Guinness, Katie Johnson.
"This sinister black comedy accelerates until it becomes a hilarious fantasy of murder. Alec Guinness plays the leader of a horrendous
gang, who has their fiendish plans upset by a cheerful old lady who lives in a world of her own." — Pauline Kael

M, 1931, Germany. Director: Fritz Lang. Cast: Peter Lorre, Ellen

Widman, Inge Landgut.
In Lorre's screen debut,he gives a flawless performance as a claustrophobic, psychotic child-rapist who is hunted both by the police and
the criminal underworld. "One of the all-time greats" — Leonard Maltin

The Grand Illusion, 1937, France. Director: Jean

Renoir. Cast: Jean Gabin, Erich von Stroheim, Pierre Fresnay.
The true story of the escape of French soldiers from a German prison camp during WWI provides the framework for pacifist Renoir's
anti-war classic. "If I had to save only one film in the world, it would be The Grand Illusion."—Orson Welles

Fanny and Alexander, 1983, Sweden. Director: Ingmar Bergman. Cast: Pernilla Allwin, Bertil Guve.
One of Bergman's last endeavors and certainly his finale, this film is a nostalgic tribute to his childhood. Though not autobiographical,
it was filmed in his boyhood town and tells of Fanny and Alexander's troubles with their new stepfather, a cruel bishop.

Metropolis, 1926, Germany. (silent

with music score) Director: Fritz Lang. Cast: Rudolph Klein-Rogge.
This science-fiction extravaganza is an elaborate, futuristic fantasy about a subterranean factory that is ruled by Titans, betrayed by robots,
and saved by love. Said to have been inspired by the New York City skyline, the sets of Metropolis are among the most imaginative and
impressive ever created for film.

The Spirit of the Beehive, 1974, Spain. Director: Victor Erice. Cast: Fernando Fernan Gomez, Ana Torrent.
Erice's brilliant directorial debut tells the story of a lonely little village girl who sees Boris Karloff's Frankenstein and then treks off into
the countryside to find the monster. "Best Spanish film ever made...there has probably never been a more extraordinary view of a child
on a movie screen." — The New York Times

Spellbound, 1945, U.S.A. Director: Alfred

Hitchcock. Cast: Ingrid Bergman, Gregory Peck, Leo G. Carroll.
In one of the first films about psychoanalysis, Peck is an amnesiac who believe he has committed murder, and Bergman is the psychiatrist
who restores him to sanity.

Black Orpheus, 1960, Brazil. Director: Marcel Camus. Cast: Breno

Mello, Marpessa Dawn.
Considered one of the most beautiful films ever made, Black Orpheus retells the legend of Orpheus and Eurydice against the madness of
a carnival in Rio de Janeiro, with its intoxicating samba music, frenzied dancing, and colorful costumes.

Knife in the Water, 1962, Poland. Director: Roman Polanski. Cast: Leon

Niemczyk, Jolanta Umecka.
A squarish couple invites a young hitchhiker to join them on a yachting weekend, but on the water the two men become very competitive
and ironically they both end up overboard. Though the plot is very simple, the dramatic outcome is a revelation of what men and women
think they are all about. "A must see movie" - Leonard Maltin.

Moreau.
This Oscar winner is a surrealistic comedy about a group of corrupt, well-to-do Parisians who keep trying, unsuccessfully, to dne together.
It is impossible to say what is real in this razor-sharp and consistently amusing social commentary.

In 1900, on the eve of the birth of the Ausatralian nation, a half-caste aborgine named Jimmie Blacksmith, after enduring a life of racism,
murders the family of his employer, and embarks on a bloody flight across thousands of miles of the awesome countryside of New South
Wales. "Go see this movie." - New York Magazine.

One of Baltimore's most
sophisticated dining spots,
located in the Baltimore
Museum of Art, is only steps
away from the Johns Hopkins
campus. While the clientele
consists mainly of patrons of
the arts, the cafe is opened to
the public for those who find
museum-going to be a less than
thrilling experience.

create an eating experience that
is both delightful and soothing.
An entire wall of glass floods
the restaurant with light and
overlooks the patio. Once the
warmer weather arrives,
customers may sit outside
where they can dine among the
museum's sculptures and
shrubbery.
The menu presents a wide
selection of unique foods and
drinks available throughout the
day and evening. The cafe offers different types of snacks
and entrees to accomodate
one's appetite and the time of
day. It is open after museum
hours, serving Lite Fare and
Dinner Tuesday-Saturday until
11:00 p.m. and Sunday until
9:00 p.m. Sunday Brunch is
available from 11:00 a.m. until 3:00 p.m. Both the museum
and the cafe are closed on
Mondays.
The lunch selections include
Pasta Primavera (a chilled
pasta salad of spinach and egg
a loodles, tossed with fresh

vegetables and imported
cheeses, $4.50), the Virginia
Club (roast turkey breast and
Smithfield Ham on light and
dark bread, $5.50), and the
Cafe Burger (a broiled burger
topped with fried onions and
melted New York cheddar
cheese, served on an onion
Kaiser roll with lettuce and
tomato, $4.95). The luncheon
menu varies in price from $4.50
to $6.50 for entrees, and from
$2.25 to $5.95 for exotic appetizers, soups and salads.
Dinner entrees, served from
5:00-10:00 p.m., are served
with a cafe salad, fresh
vegetables, and a basket of
warm rye sticks. Starting at
$8.50, Tortellini with Pesto is
deliciously prepared in a broccoli walnut sauce and seasoned
with pesto. If one has an occasion to celebrate or simply
desires a special culinary treat,
Tournedos Dijonnaise (two
petit filet mignons on Dijon
mustard croutons, served with
a sauce of burgundy wine,
shallots, and mushrooms,
$12.95) is highly recommended.
After dinner, one may
choose a scrumptious selection
from the pastry tray and try one
of many teas, coffees, dessert
drinks, or cordials.
Whether you are strolling
through the museum and are
overcome by hunger, or feel
that you deserve to sample
superior fare, the Museum Cafe
should rise to the top of your
list.
